When a small group of organisms (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it came (e.g. when they cross a mountain range or a river, or when they settle on a new island, so that they cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, rather than what they needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
Over time the new population begins to adapt to its new environment, and then it begins to look less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years, two populations look so different that they can no longer be classified as the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the creation of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by the underlying logic that is associated with scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. One, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely beyond cultural or political influence, and two, that technology itself has "effects" on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
One could say that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.

The widespread ownership of automobiles also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new technologies in the healthcare industry to repair damaged bodies.

During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, which are now known as "Dunlap broadsides".
The first public reading of the document took place by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.

The 25 Dunlap broadsides that remain are the oldest surviving copies of the document. The original handwritten document has not survived the ages.

Field trips are an important part of every school class. Often a teacher would like to take her students to places where a bus trip is not an option.
Virtual excursions are a technological solution. Students can view museum pieces from the classroom, visit an aquarium or admire beautiful works of art.
Sharing a virtual excursion is also a great way to reflect on a trip and to share experiences with future classes.

For example, students from the Bennet School in North Carolina design a website every year about their trip to the state capital. The website is redesigned every year, but the previous versions remain online and serve as a scrapbook.

Blogs can also help to improve the writing skills of students. Although students at the beginning of their blogging experience often have a sloppy grammar and spelling, this usually changes when there is an audience.
Students are often a very critical audience, so the blog author makes an effort to improve his writing style to avoid criticism.
Blogging "forces the students to learn more about the world around them." The need to attract the reader's interest inspires the students to write cleverly and interestingly (Toto, 2004).
Blogging is a tool that inspires collaboration and encourages students to continue learning outside of the traditional school day.

The appropriate use of blogs "can enable students to become more analytical and critical; through the active reaction to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of the texts of others and to express their own perspectives on certain topics" (Oravec, 2002).

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa. It borders Mozambique to the east, Zimbabwe to the north and the Crocodile River to the south.
The park has an area of 19,500 km2 and is divided into 14 different ecosystems, each supporting a different animal life.
It is one of the main attractions of South Africa and is regarded as the flagship of the South African National Parks (SANParks).
Like all South African national parks, the park charges daily conservation and entrance fees.
It can also be worthwhile to buy a Wild Card which grants access either to selected parks in South Africa or to all South African National Parks.

The Sundarbans were designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest within the Indian state is called Sundarbans National Park.
The forests are not only mangrove swamps – they also include some of the last remaining stands of the mighty jungle that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which a third is covered by water and marshes.
The Sundarbans are a nature reserve since 1966, and estimates suggest that there are now 400 Bengal tigers and about 30,000 spotted deer in the area.

Their two towers are 83 m high, their length is 378 m and they have two lanes with a width of 3.5 m.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP), which is pegged to the value of the British Pound (GBP).

Credit cards are unlikely to be accepted on the remote islands, though British and U.S. currency may be accepted; check with the owners in advance to find out what payment methods are accepted.

Spurs are aids for the feet of riders, which hang down on both sides of the saddle.
They give the rider more stability, but there are safety concerns because the rider's feet may get caught in them.
If a rider falls off the horse and gets caught in the stirrup, he can be dragged along if the horse runs. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a fairly narrow sole.
In addition, some saddles, especially English saddles, have safety buckles that allow a riding girth to fall, should it be pulled backwards by a falling rider.

Japanese work culture is hierarchical and formal than what Westerners may be used to.
Suits are part of the standard business attire and colleagues address each other with their family names or job titles.
